content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												When I bought Hydrophobia, I was expecting dynamic gameplay revolving around an awesome ability allowing the manipulation of water. Upon playing the game, I realized this is not much more than a repetitive tech demo for water physics. The gameplay is alright, but I found it to be quite boring. When I finally attained the ability to manipulate water, I found it to be lacking in functionality, and discovered that it is only useable on the final boss and in a few rooms before it.I also realized, that in order to attain 100% completion of the game, you need to be able to accomplish a difficult and unclear task on the first attempt. After failing the task once, it can not be attempted again. The only way to get 100% at that point, is to manually delete the save and to restart from the very beginning. This can be tedious to do as the task is found at the end of Act 1 or the beginning of Act 2, so you have to play for quite a while to get back, and you also have to reattain every medal that you might have had at that point, which in my case was all but two or three.The game includes a feedback option that allows you to choose aspects of the game that you did or did not like. Upon researching the company that made the game, I found out that they went bankrupt and that the feedback is now meaningless.Overall I'd say that this game is extremely disappointingly repetitive and lacking in gameplay, but I suppose that it is worth its low price.

												As majority of people say, not even worth the 0.49€ as many (including me) bought it for. Yes, the water physics and look is gorgeous, but that is it. The rest is absolutely awfull. They should never have made it like this, why not just make a physics engine video and spare the money on making this atrocity.1. Cutscenes -> huge ton of them, first you have a cutscene, then walk 2 meters (no joke, 2 meters, or even less), another cutscene, another 2 meters, another cutscene, another 3 meters, yet another cutscene. This game is filled with useless cutscenes that could have been done differently. There are cutscenes hidden as a dialogue, as camera feeds, as danger, they are everywhere to the point where I spent 15 times grabbing and letting go of my mouse every minute.2. Voice acting is just bad, main protagonist is so irritating I wanted to kill her myself, and the male support role jokes in so many stupid ways that I would smack him through the radio. There is difference between being a smartass and being a complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ when you make a completely stupid joke as you're about to die.3. Bugs, oh so many, game is brutally linear and nothing wrong with that, but even being linear and with everything shining at you at where you're supposed to go, I got myself stuck several times to the point I couldn't find a way further. Small room, nowhere to go, nothing to shoot/press/do.1 hour wasted, 0.49€ wasted. Should have bought myself a beer instead, pour it into a glass, marvel at the water physics and then drink it. would be much better experience.

Posted: October 26, 2014
												This game was originally released in an unfinished state, and consequently received a very bad reputation as result.  However, the developer has gone back and addressed most of the complaints and the result is a fun, technically impressive game that is well worth the money when on-sale. The controls, gameplay, and graphics are all above-average for a budget game and you will see things being done with water physics that you won't see in other games of this type.  If you enjoy third person shooters and/or neat water in games then you really can't go wrong.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This is a game about water. Oh, all right; the game is actually about shooting people in first person view on a sinking ship, but that's really besides the point. Hydrophobia utilizes a proprietary engine (the "HydroEngine") that realistically renders the ebb and flow of liquids, and this feature is the game's main attraction. Watching the waves crash around is fascinating; it really is quite impressive technology.The rest of the game is quite ordinary, however. The PC version is significantly improved over the original released on the XBox,  and features entirely new levels and a story that actually closes satisfactorily. But it is nothing we haven't seen a hundred times before and - once the thrill of watching the water move drains away - there's little reason to come back to the game.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2013
												Hydrophobia is a 3rd person action / shooter based around some great water dynamics. The water will flow from one room to the next, raise, lower, put out fires, and electricity will damage anything near it. Its a lot like being in a Zelda water dungeon. This is a good game with gameplay mechanics that are on par with big budget games like Uncharted and Batman: Arkham Asylum. It has the ledge climbing, destructible environments, swimming, camera hacking, wall cover, sneaking and even a Navi, which is similar to Arkham Asylum's detective mode, which will let you find encryption codes on walls, open doors from a far, hack consoles with a mini game, access cameras.There's a great balance between problem solving, shooting and exploration. There are only a few guns and really you won't need any other gun but the default phaser that you can hold the trigger to charge for bigger damage. There is a cover system, but I rarely used it. The downside for some purists would be the aim seems off since there's a 'target lock' system. What I mean is aim near something you can shoot and it lights red and will still count as a hit. Its not the best, but it stays in the realm of good. Even though the game encourages you to drown foes, electrocute them, blow up barrels and so on, it didn't really seem like I killed anyone in cool ways other than exploding barrels.The controls feel good, aim, shoot, move, move camera, roll (although I never used it once), jump, sneak, weapon wheel, diving, emerging, sticking to cover and so on. The heroine's movement is just a little stiff, but that's one of the only downsides to this game.The story is good for an indie action game, terrorists have taken over your cruise ship and you need to stop them. You've got a helpful voice that chimes in and tells you what to do, but it never feels like too much instruction. There are things left for yourself to figure out. There's even a nice waypoint to guide you in the general direction if you chose to use it to make the game easier for you to stay on task. It will always show you a dot on the screen where you need to go, but getting to that point is on you.The game looks great, with really nice water effects and camera sprays. The voice acting sounds good and there are an over abundance of cut scenes at the start, but they ease up in frequency as the game goes on.I've got the game on PSN and PC. Graphics wise I'd say PC is better, but it seems to be a beast on my PC's processor and not the graphics card. It is a game best played with a controller. The downside with PC is the camera feels chaotic.The game is short and sweet. The whole single player campaign is like 3 - 4 hours (I completed it for PSN) and at less than $5 I'm fine with that. There are challenge rooms to extend the game's length. It doesn't overstay its welcome and its a game that makes me want to play other things that the developers come up with, but alas they're defunct as of 2012.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												This is a tricky game to review, and it really makes me wish that Steam had a neutral option. Although the description boasts about allowing you to control water, you don't actually gain this ability until the tail end of the game. This is rather unfortunate, as this power is what makes the game worth playing in the first place. Without this ability this is a mediocre game at best. It is buggy, generic, and sometimes a bit of an annoyance. However, I still enjoyed my time playing this game mainly due to how impressed I was by the water physics. It seems as though the entire budget for this game went in to this aspect, and it really does pay off. The water is lots of fun to play with, and is fantastically animated.I would recommend ONLY buying this if you are willing to play through the lackluster first half of the game just to reach what is essentially a water physics demo. I bought this game on sale for $0.50, and was happy with the experience I got for this price.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												Straight up, I don't recommend this as a game. This is one of the most average third person shooters I have ever played. It's not necessarily a bad game, but it's not worth playing if you aren't going to buy it for the water effects/physics. If you are okay with a tech demo, then consider getting it.Hydrophobia: Prophecy was developed by an indie company, so straight away you know that it won't easily compete with the best TPS games out there.If I had to compare the entire game to other games, I would say that they took the climbing mechanics from Tomb Raider/Uncharted and made the sinking ship level from "Tomb Raider: Underworld" into a game.The game was made for almost no other reason than to show off the engine. It has dynamic water with physics that are incredible. You can shoot out windows to flood rooms even more and the water can either help you in combat or it will just make things more difficult. Unfortunately the game is short and doesn't really speed up. The game is apparently the first in a series, but when you are playing a 4 year old game, you know that there won't be a sequel any time soon.The gameplay would be far too unacceptable if it weren't for the water mechanics. It's essentially a corridoor shooter with an upturned bucket of water over it. Most of the time you'll die because you didn't know what the game wanted you to do. The waypoints and tips from your work partner who is known as "Scoot" are overdone as they literally tell you how to get through each section of the game. The character development is so weak that it shouldn't have even existed.The controls are okay most of the time, but the camera does not want to go under the water, so it really limits how far you can look up or down, which is really annoying when there are 3 metre waves flying everywhere.The story is just a lame excuse for a giant city on a boat to start sinking. Basically a bunch of terrorists claim that in order to save the world, they need to kill everybody on board. The story is weak as anything I'm afraid.The water is definitely the main focus of the game, as waves crash against you and send crates floating in all directions. I especially love it when you open a door and the water from the room you were in slowly seeps through. The water can appear almost gel-like at times, but since it was an innovation that literally tested the water (heheh), I can forgive it.This game could have shown how water can really change up the gameplay of a game, but unfortunately, they didn't make the mechanics good enough for it. The potential was there, but the presentation was sub-par.Unfortunately, no other games used this engine and other engines are starting to produce better effects, which is making this game even more obsolete and mediocre. Some things just don't get better with age.

number of helpful: 12 of 12 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												So, Hydrophobia: Prophecy; What a weird name for a game where the main protagonist isn't afraid of drinking water, nor is there any mention of a prophecy of sorts in the story. It's like the devs skimmed through a list of words with a hydro- prefix, picked the one that sounded cool, and added the "prophecy" subtitle so it looks like there's going to be a grand "chosen one" adventure. I think that they were trying to tie the title's name with their in-house "HydroEngine[en.wikipedia.org]", but in my opinion, they should have gone with something that represents the game properly.Hydrophobia looks like it was made to showcase the HydroEngine (which is impressive), and that's kind of where the problem stems from. Everything about this game is bad; the voice acting, gameplay mechanics, and story are all lackluster, compared to other indie games within the same price range. Sure, the water simulations are great, but why didn't the devs use that as the core gameplay mechanic, instead of shoving it as a background element? The player could have controlled the water ala waterbending, used it so solve complex puzzles, and employed to create tension in some stages - all we were left with is a so-so TPS, with a hodgepodge of game mechanics that's borrowed from other titles.Regarding the story: well, the story is forgettable. They've got this protagonist who has all of the excuses and skills to navigate a sinking ship, with a voice actor who is clearly trying to sound American, but slips in her native Irish accent once in a while. She's got some kind of a backstory that's shown in the opening cutscene, where aquaphobia has troubled her all her life, yet she swims like a pro - and it doesn't get mentioned ever again throughout the game. After the intro, everything regarding character development is thrown out of the window, in favor of a story that's all about escaping flooded rooms.If someone could pick up this IP, and revise some of the decisions made before, I'll definitely have a look at it. The industry rarely tackles games like this, and it would be a shame to just let a concept like this one die out. But choose a better name next time; something like "Hydropower", or "Hydroelectric". Better yet, name it "Aquaphobia".And there you have it.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												Hmmm. Where do I start? Personally, I purchased this game due to curiosity, and because it seemed really-really interesting, and of course, it was on sale. I was a bit disappointed at first, but intrigued by the game engine used. The game has incredible water physics.I recommend this game for the same reason why I purchased it. if you're curious, seems interesting & it is on sale.Things to consider if you're planning on purchasing:Graphics:The graphics setting is not in-game but pre-game. Which means you have no option on changing the graphics setting when you are in game. Graphics at medium setting dropped my FPS. Compared to other games published in 2011 that I've played, this is not supposed to happen.Somehow the game crashed, probably due to the processing of the graphics.Controls:You will always be sprinting, even at the beginning of the game where you're in your residence. Its annoying, really. You can always crouch to walk to avoid sprinting.When you use the flash light, there is light but your character is not holding any flash light. I'm assumming the light comes from her headband. I'm using a Logitech F310 gamepad with this game and overall, I think the controls are okay.  Map:The map interface design is very weird. Interesting, but weird. The map control using the F310 gamepad is weird. Moving the map using the gamepad is very troublesome. I have not tried it with a mouse thoughCharacter Background Development:You will know that the main character, Kate has a water-related phobia. (as the name of the game suggests)You will wonder what the word Prophecy in the game title actually means.  No story was developed around the word Prophecy.When you dive, having less than 50% of oxygen left, you will hear things. (this annoys me a lot)Through the end of the game, you will not know what happened to Scoot, Kate's partner who guided her throughout the game.You will wonder what S.A.R.A. is and when were you introduced or atleast warned about it.You will end up with a major cliffhanger playing this game.This is a game I'd recommend to new game developers, to learn what not to do in designing the game, learn from the mistakes made making this game.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
Full Review[yarow12.tumblr.com]Hydrophobia: Prophecy's main problem lies in the (only) boss fight and ending. The endboss is hell to deal with, but not too difficult once you figure it out (don't run out of barrels or you're screwed). The ending itself is... episodic. It wouldn't be a problem if a sequel was in the works, but this is highly unlikely so our best chances of satisfaction lie in getting a spiritual successor to a pretty great 10-hour game that has many surprising qualities that make it oh so worth playing. It even managed to take me back to my earlier days of gaming.There may only be one general path to follow at all times with some side/backtracking included, but I never noticed because of how expansive the ship that 98% of the game takes place on felt. The in-game map is very useful, by the way.There are tons (72?) of collectibles (objects, documents, Malthus documents) and medals.Wait, stop running! What's that on the shelf? Go grab it. Awesome, document 24 out of 48 found.There are multiple ways to take on enemies.Can you not, to save your own life, shoot a moving target? Aim for an explosive barrel (boom), electrical conduit (electrical boom), gas tank (flaming boom), or electrical wire (zzzap) that's conveniently hanging above a large puddle of water.Tired of taking cover during shootouts? Flood the room by shooting holes in breakable walls and windows. Have fun aiming up, down, and all around as enemies shoot you from every direction while completely underwater.The game's story and lore lies in the hidden messages left on the walls (think Bioshock) by the Malthusians--eco-friendly terrorists who love the environment more than your life (prepare to be disturbed). These messages can only be viewed using the MAVI scanner--a badass tablet that can hack cameras and consoles (fun, but tricky to get 100% perfection); download ciphers to unlock encrypted doors; reveal how much water will fill the room once a door is opened; and open the door 'cause ♥♥♥♥ that fire.The in-game database is basically your bestiary or encyclopedia of Hydrophobia.Found a bottle of sleeping pills in your apartment? Read about it and learn more about this attractive female you're playing as. Or say "♥♥♥♥ it" and continue your shooting spree.Scanned another hidden message left by the Malthusians? Read one of many interesting excerpts from "From the works of Thomas Malthus".Hate universal ammo (think Deus Ex: Invisible War)? How about a reversal? Universal gun, baby! One gun; five ammo types (rapid-fire, gel, sonic, energy, explosive).The following lag fix may or may not work with other games aswell. Use at your own risk.Ctrl+Shift+Esc (Windows Task Manager > Processes) > Right-click Hydrophobia: Prophecy > Set Priority > Normal.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												I went back and forth a lot on this game. When it runs well it's a pretty fun 3PS, but there's weird bugs all the time, and you can just randomly die with very little warning (because of a fire thats under the water you can't see). I like the storyline, not to give away spoilers but it's kind of bioshockish, but I can't be bothered to read 400 journal entries, so I can't say for sure. What I get from cutscenes and character conversations is pretty interesting. The controls are pretty terrible though (at least the underwater ones) when you're swimming and you press spacebar the camera will freak out like a cat in a tumble drier and spin uncontrollably while you push your head against whatevers above you. If there isn't anything above you, then you'll IMMEDIATELY surface. Press C to go down, which immediately pins you to the floor. Swimming is pretty rough, and this is compounded by the fact that the game celebrates its water physics. The cover based shooting isn't bad, cover to cover works, I don't get what sprint does, except that she leaps forward about 5 feet then resumes regular walking speed. Also the majority of my deaths were from her not quite making a jump correctly, or invisible fireballs in the water (or from trying to get a stupid diary near fire that pretty much insta kills you). Rarely did the AI have a hand in any of my injuries.The enemy AI is dumb as a box of rocks, and will scan every square inch of where you aren't. They'll miss constantly, which isn't always a good thing as there always seems to be 400 exploding barrels and electrical boxes nearby. Though there's a point where you have to "stealth kill" using an exploding bullet (yes, I typed that correctly) but the stupid thing hits the corner of a pillar every time and never goes where you want it. In more open firefights its useful, but the thing is supposed to be stealthy.I like this game, I do, but the bugs kind of kill it, and honestly if this was from a bigger developer, or not under 50 cents I don't think I'd reccomend it. I might pay a few bucks for it, because it is pretty good, but its just kind of a let down for much more.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
												A tale of two games, Hydrophobia prophecy starts wonderfully. Trapped aboard a city-sized ship as it is attacked by terrorists, you must survive and hide with your heroine's athletic climbing abilities. You'll be climbing and swinging on pipes and scaffolding to make your way around. Swimming is a large aspect as water fills hallways and elevator shafts. The effects are beautiful and the water will knock around objects. Eventually you get a gun but combat starts minimal. The story seems interesting and there are cool notes scattered around. You can hack cameras and use them to open doors. There are even a few water puzzles.Then everything takes a turn for the worse in the 3rd act. There is way too much combat and not enough of the platforming or climbing. You get the ability to control water somehow, but only get 1 power and it's a bit hard to control. More importantly, it's a "weapon" so you have either that or your pistol. The problem is that it doesn't switch well and it's difficult to attack using the water, which is what a player obviously wants to do. The game ends with a terrible boss fight that emphasizes the combat, which is the worst part of this game. The story just ends with no follow up on the other people you came into contact with.I really enjoyed the first two thirds, but the final act was a horrible, frustrating, chore.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												In sum, it's a very-very-very mediocre 3-view shooter with female heroine on the big ship which was stormed by terrorists. It has a quite simplistic gameplay, where nothing is original, but, on the top of all - it is so short, that it looks like demo-version, and not a complete game.I've already finished that game once (not on Steam), and I'll do it second time, but only because I've been a bad boy, and need to be punished.What exactly do I have against that game, you may ask me? Well, the same thing we all have against cheaters and other freaks in the multiplayer: they destroy our hopes to have a good time.Now goes the major spoiler: this game ending, when normal player is only warming up to some contest. Remember that we were promised by blurb? Control above the water! Just look at the title screen: there you are, a water-driving superwoman!In the game, there are only three acts, and the first two of them can be counted as a prologue. You start normally, step by step you're getting the game's mechanics, climbing and diving through the first trials, saving some powerful ammo for the rest of the game. Then goes the first serious shootout, where you probably might use some of the powerful shots you've collected. Then you learning to control water... two more rooms, and then BLAM! - the boss fight! And that's all!The Hydrophobia could have been a very good game... but it seems that over 95% of resources were spended strictly on the engine. We don't have enough game there, just a little prolonged presentation of that precious engine.It usually can be finished in less than 5 hours... But there is a Major Bug with savegames (there are single checkpoint system). Every now and then when you're restarting Hydrophobia, it drops your savefiles to the pit of Oblivion. Sometimes they returning... after 4-5 reloading. Mostly - don't. There are other bugs, as well, but loosing the savegame looks like the game feature, which is more fluent than water itself!I hate that game for what she could be - a very nice looking, smart-enough sleep-taker. But in our reality she's just a soother. 5.5/10 mark. You'll be much better with the Bioshock and Tomb Raider titles. And if you're really want some challenge,,, find Heavy Metal FAKK 2 - that's a real deal!

The action revolves around maneuvering through short mazes of flooded hallways, solving a few puzzles using the water mechanics, and getting into firefights, both above and under water. As you may have noticed, water plays a HUGE role in this game, and it should. Hydrophobia has some of the best water physics I have ever seen. It is almost worth playing just to mess around with the water physics.

content:
Posted: March 8
												TLDR: a game featuring interesting water physics and mediocre everythingelse. Worth the usual asking price of 0.50€ during sales  (but what wouldn't worth for that money?) but I'm not sure if it's worth your time.It may be interesting on a proper, strong computer if you want to check a tech-demo of water physics, but as a game it's horribly optimized - just as a reference as my laptop's specs wouldn't say much. I can play Arkham Asylum on 1366*768 without much changes I think medium-ish graphics with 30-60 fps. In Hydrophobia I got 19 fps in the credits. It's a scrolling white text before black background.As I said, the game is more of a tech demo. Opening doors with water behind them makes the water pour out, changing the water level, pushing items and you backwards, explosions don't just slash but really make the water moving, which is nice. But this does not serve as an excuse to have messy keyboard controls, way too high mouse sensitivity with mandatory autoaim, using a controller is gimped because not having reversed Y, only X axis, and the enemies often just forget to shoot you. They just walk in front of you, not even noticing you, even during the bossfight. Gameplay: Third person, consisting about shooting, running, ladder- and pipeclimbing, door-opening and repeating a hacking minigame. It's incredibly unoriginal.The bossfight at the end is also a letdown. You get powers to control water during the story which is cool, but the previous reviews were right - you get the power about TWO rooms before the bossfight, so you throw a bench away, complete a simple but well-used puzzle with the powers, shoot a few soldiers and there you go, bossfight, use your power to defeat it, woohoo!

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Hydrophobia is an enjoyable little game that can easily be finished in two to three hours. It's a platformer with mild shooting elements set on a floating city beseiged by Malthusian-inspired terrorists.The game is surprisingly feature rich for a small title like this, and the water effects are particularly impressive. You can open doors to flood rooms or drain them, you can use water to knock down and stun enemies, and you can also use water to overcome environmental hazards like fires or stray electrical wires. There's also a novel hacking minigame.Considering the length, I'd appraise the game at $5.00 to $7.50 at most, and anything equal to or beneath that price point is a steal. There's a plot, but it's told mainly through picked up documents. There's also a few fun little easter eggs for gamers.If you like aquatic games, platforming, and blowing people away with a sonic pistol, then I recommend you check this one out.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												If I had to sum up Hydrophobia in three words it would be "two-thirds awesome".  What I mean by that is that the first two acts of the game are really quite good, mixing together something that is a blend of parkour, exploration, and wonderfully detailed water physics.  It's only in the third act that things go a bit pearshaped.First though, let's talk about the good.  The most obvious is, of course, the water physics.  Oh man does this game spend a lot of time on water physics.  It flows, moves, cascades, splashes, washes over things, shows visible eddies and flows, and pushes things around as it is manipulated.  Most importantly though, your character reacts to it believably.  At no time did I feel like I was witnessing some badly out of place animation or hacky changeover from walking to swimming physics.  That also helped with the game's immersion greatly, which is good because the world presented in Hydrophobia is fairly interesting.  Though it doesn't go into much detail about the history and backround of the world, the game's areas are rich with ambiance and little touches that make it feel well designed and deep.Another tally in the good category are the game's "puzzles", such as they are.  While less a matter of clever puzzling and more a matter of "find the thing you need to shoot, push, or interact with", there's a lot of creativity involved in getting to those things sometimes. There's a clever little hacking minigame that comes up where you basically match a waveform, which is delightfully satisfying without being too easy.  More often than not it winds up being some mix of water trickery or environment climbing a la Prince of Persia, which brings me to my next good thing: your character's parkour moves.  Much like the interaction with water, at no point did I feel like I was watching some crap animations play out while my character progressed along the game's expected linear path.  Movement felt smooth, limber, agile.  The controls for all this climbing could have been explained better, but once I figured them out it was easy enough.  It's satisfying to watch too.Okay, so on to the other stuff: the bad stuff.  What's bad in this game?  The combat, mostly.  To be fair, in the first two acts it's not bad so much as just there, enemies serving more as other obstacles to get around.  The interior of the ship is littered with environmental hazards you can use to trip up enemies, which is amusing, and if you have to shoot it out with them the single gun you get is decent enough.  Where it becomes a problem though is the third act, because the third act is focused almost exclusively around combat rather than all the exploration and water puzzles you'd been getting good at.  If combat was a bit snappier and less, well, repetitive and tedious then it wouldn't be so bad.  As it is the transition makes you feel like you wandered into the wrong game by accident.With that going badly for it, the third act makes things worse by committing a few of the big no-nos of game design.  Probably the worst example I can think of is spawning more enemies in areas you just cleared as you get closer to them.  One area in particular was utterly maddening, as I would clean out the area before proceeding across a rather narrow exterior walkway, only to come around and find a guy popping into existence just in time to shotgun me in the face.  I don't mean he came out of a nearby door (there weren't any) I mean he literally appeared in a formely empty space and started shooting me.  In previous acts the additions of new waves of enemies was justified by your actions activating alarms, with said enemies coming from nearby doors.  In the third act all pretense is dropped, and the game suffers greatly for it.I can't comment on the final boss, other than to say that unlike virtually everyone else I found it ridiculously easy (water powers, throw barrel, repeat).  I do think it was a bit out of place given the rest of the game at least.  The ending is a bit abrupt - you can tell they were trying to sell this as being episodic or needing a sequel - but it at least has some resolution to it.The only other thing I can say gameplay wise is that the game's "water powers" are squandered in the most tragic of ways.  Though the controls are a little counterintuitive, the biggest problem is that you get them for an incredibly brief time.  While they aren't amazing, they are at least impressive, and yet I had maybe a half hour of gameplay to use them before I'd reached the end.With all of that said, I still had fun playing Hydrophobia. The core of the gameplay is fun, the story is a bit simplistic but engaging all the same, and the characters are memorable and easily likeable/hateable as appropriate.  As I said, I love the ambiance of the game, and I would enjoy seeing more content set in the same world, be it a sequel or something else.  I think I got my money's worth out of the game, but I hope that if there is a sequel the developers keep the puzzle-exploration to combat ratio a bit more consistent throughout it.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												This game is abysmal. Although it initially appears that you can at least get entertainment from how terrible the writing and acting are, the actual gameplay quickly ruins any good will you could poissbly have towards it. This is, hands down, the worst game I've ever finished and one of the worst games I've ever played. It's utterly beyond me how anyone could possibly give this mess a positive review. Pros:- 3 hours long. The tortue is brief. - The shooting and Uncharted-like platforming controls are functional. - You have a magic tablet that always knows where you should go. It suffers from Borderlands 1-esque "walk through this mountain" directions, but generally cancels out the poor level design. Cons:- Terrible voice acting. The main character in particular expresses almost no emotion. - Terrible story. It's your standard misguided future ecoterrorists ruining a supposed utopia. Characters appear and disappear, what should be major plot points are thrown out after two seconds of discussion, and the ending resolves absolutely nothing. A sequel was clearly planned, but never happened. - Uninteresting world. It's a boat, and almost all of it looks the same. - Constant spawn in. Enemies just appear wherever they want, particularly after you press switches. They do very little damage and die instantly to your basic, infinite rounds, which means the game is basically whack-a-mole. - Awful controls. You get the games big physics power in the last 20 minutes, and the buttons to switch to and from using it simply don't work. I had to mash the key for it up to 10 times in order to switch, which is a huge problem during a boss fight. Walking and swimming are also bad. - Poor level design. If not for the aforementioned magic tablet, this would have been a 20 hour game from me never knowing where to go. - Crap hacking minigame. Match the wave displayed on screen by waving your mouse around. - Terrible physics. Water does not work the way this game thinks it does, which is a big problem when the game is entirely based around its water physics. I had repeated issues with water flowing in to closed areas and magically not filling them or with the flow between two rooms somehow never levelling out. Once I had a roomfull of water simply disappear! The barrel physics and whatnot are pretty bad as well, which is surprising since this supposedly used Havoc. Might be collision issues with the environment. - Stability and performance. Steam vents do a number on the framerate. I had two crashes and once instance of a trigger not firing and having to restart. Hydrophobia: Prophecy is a terrible game that isn't worth your time even if you get it for free. There's no enjoyment to be had after the first half hour. If you absolutely must play with water physics today, find a bathtub.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												There's a lot of little elements that make this game great however it has its rough edges.*The graphics are really good imho although the world feels a bit too bland at times but that's probably a design choice (you're on board of an ultra modern ship)*The music could be better, it's not really that memorable.*The controls feel a bit clunky at times (playing on PC with keyboard and mouse)it's easy enough to play though, but sometimes when alternating between diving & swimming at the surface & walking in deep water for example, it's kinda hard to predict your character precise movements.*The water physics are great though I feel like there is room for even more improvement (I'm not sure how realistic they are though, I'm not a liquid physician)*The story is engaging and felt original enough to me, however sometimes some elements of the gameplay could have been given a little more of a dramatic feeling. I won't say more so as not to spoil anything.*The level design is overall alright, with a good mix of action & tomb raider like jumping & stuff. However it's a total corridor game, nothing is open ended here ever.Therefore if you get this game you can turn off the "waypoints" option.And finally a personnal gripe : yet another game with regenerative health, I abused it though because the enemies do hurt a lot when you get surprised.I have not finished the game yet, but I would honestly like Hydrophobia 2 to come our way and in my opinion it's worth more than the 1€ I paid for it on sale.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
Teal DeerDevelopers: Dark Energy Digital Ltd Publishers: Dark Energy Digital Ltd Initial release: May 2011Genre: Action, Adventure, Environment Puzzles #Worth/NotWorth: #NotWorth Exposition, Concurrence and SummationHydrophobia is a game in which attempts to evoke Under Siege mixed with Tomb Raider and brings elements from Watch Dogs and Psi-Ops.… but it does a terrible job of doing all of those things.I thought going in this would be a smaller budget title with light platforming and puzzle solving.. mostly using water. I was wrong. Its pretty much just a shooter. That wouldn't be a bad thing if it were good at that. The mechanics of shooting just barely qualify as competent. The nicest things I can say about the game are as follows:- The swimming isn't completely busted- The cut-scenes actually seem decent as if someone actually spent time on those. - There are multiple types of ammo (none of which feel good)- Its easier to tell when people are dead underwater- The game ends eventually.I have no idea what compelled me to play this until the credits were rolling. I guess mostly because I had already invested some time and Howlongtobeat.com said I didn't have much further to go. So I suffered through the injustice in the name of due diligence.The voice acting isn't awful either but its certainly far from being good. If you really like B list Sci Fi original movies then this will be right up your alley but if not just stay clear.Follow my curation for more

Posted: July 10, 2012
												Short and unsatisfying.For most of the storyline (a very apt estimate), water will mainly serve as a puzzle you can't directly influence.Room upon room, water is either a hazard through loose electric wires (shoot the wires - puzzle solved), a requirement to get past fire (lots of that) but rarely makes you feel like suffocating.And what about that water controlling stuff? You get it halfway Act 3 (the last act) with one trick, the water tower. Which serves for rarely anything more then heavy, uninspired lifting.The boss is even worse, it's uninspired and unsatisfying to beat it.The ending is basically a plothole. Villain defeated but the boat is still messed up with you in the thick of it, having just taken the antidote to remove your awesome powers (WHY???) .Forget magically controlling liquids, you rarely get enough time with it to appreciate it to its fullest.Hydrophobia is a water game. Sounds boring? It is boring.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												After getting some much-needed post-release work, Hydrophobia: Prophecy turned into a pretty decent third-person action game. It combines light platforming, combat and puzzle elements, none particularly amazing but which work when taken as a whole. The visuals and water physics are mind-blowing at times, and the story has some philosophically interesting (if not terribly original or in-depth) overtones. I believe it was ported from XBL, so a controller might come in handy.The main drawbacks are 1) the very short length, and 2) the fact that some of the coolest stuff in the game is held out until the very end, such that you hardly get to use it. Combat isn't bad, but it's simplistic, revolving around different types of ammo fired from the same weapon. The developer having gone under means this one is probably a relic now. Still, it's a good budget title and well worth the few hours of gameplay it offers.

												Even though the entire game follows the same formulas like an older third-person shooter, for what the developers were striving to achieve, the game is fairly good.Keep in mind that the developers' goal for this game was to build an excellent water physics engine, which was cutting-edge for 2011. content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												This game looked like it had a lot of promise. And several mechanics enabled this: Ammo types, environment damage, puzzles that were simple but worked, good aiming and movement(minus platforming, see further on), an interesting setting and mystery. This game however suffers from a massive lack of full content leaving a primary ability you get later in the game the most short lived part of this game. It feels like this game stops at "End of Chapter 1" and never continues. Huge disappointment.The other thing I had insane problems with were two platforming Assassin's Creed/Uncharted/Tomb Raider spots, that required you jump from one climbing spot across a gap behind the character. The camera and controls made this near impossible and incredibly frustrating. You have to hold ‘back’ on the controls to have the character face where you want to go, but once you press ‘jump’ your character finds you still holding the ‘back’ direction so she doesn’t leap far enough forward, meaning she falls, usually to her death forcing you to restart. Luckily, instantly dying was sometimes negated in the second instance of this by landing on a surface not far enough down to instantly kill the character, but you’d still have to climb all the way back up to try again… and fail.If these guys ever expand this game into a full story, and get rid of or fix the stupid platforming crap then this game would be worth a full $60 bucks as a real AAA game. But for now, pick it up on sale and spend a few minutes playing and then never play it again.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2013
												Hydrophobia:  Prophecy (Dark Energy Digital, 2011)I've completed Hydrophobia: Prophecy and had a great time doing so.  It's true that this was originally meant to be the first game in a trilogy, that it had major problems upon release, that the rest of the trilogy was scrapped and a new version of this game created that incorporated (some) content from what were meant to be the follow-ups, and that it has since appeared dirt cheap in numerous bundled deals and on Steam.  But don't let any of that distract you from what is now, today, a polished product that is genuinely fun to play.In short, Hydrophobia:  Prophecy is an action-adventure game with strong platforming elements, set on a huge ocean liner, or rather in the bowels of a huge ocean liner.  The gameplay is fairly standard.  You are able to shoot, with a variety of different projectiles at your disposal, but it's not a shooter by any stretch.The level design is great, the controls work, defeating enemies and overcoming environmental challenges feel satisfying, and as mentioned above, the price is likely to be right regardless of where you choose to buy it.SCORESGraphics - 82 %Water effects are brilliant;  the main character has terrible hair though (plastic dreadlocks on what is otherwise a gorgeous model), which I found somewhat distracting throughout.Sound - 70 %It works;  nothing particularly noteworthy though.Execution - 75 %The game, in this iteration, is a good execution of its core concept.  The storytelling via cinematics and viewscreens placed around the ship is effective.  You dislike the bad guys;  though sadly their politics are never as deeply explored as it could have been (likely owing to the trilogy being scrapped).  The free running-style gameplay and acrobatics work and never pose any problems, such as unexpected falls or missing jumps because of problematic surface detection.  One does feel that the setting (a huge ocean liner) could have been more interestingly presented, and it doesn't feel all that much like you're inside a huge ship on the ocean (regardless of copious amounts of water).  Again, it is likely that this concept was originally meant to be explored further.  The water manipulation powers from later in the game also feel a bit tacked on, as they obviously were, considering they weren't meant to be in the first episode at all.Addictiveness - 80 %I wanted to continue playing, and I did, and I pursued some achievements, and I enjoyed myself.  That sentence has about two "ands" too many, but hey, the game is a bit like that.  You never know if you're close to the end and you don't really care.  It's fun getting there, and that's mainly what matters (in my opinion).Overall - 75 %It's cheap.  It's good.  Buy it if you're into third-person exploration games with some shooting and a lot of acrobatics.  The achievements all appear to work, which I know is important to some people.  There are collectables, again, if that is your sort of thing.  I just wanted a thrilling experience with an unsual setting, and I got what I wanted.  I'm looking forward to doing another playthrough at some point.  And that's really the best recommendation there is.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												The water looks fantastic, and there are a lot of really good elements to this game, but there are some unfortunate killer flaws that bring me to not recommend it.The first and most important issue is there is a point in the game you simply can not go past due to a design issue.  Forums indicate that this is somewhat random and may be passable by messing with video settings.  The problem there is your card/driver/settings should never impact the mechanics of the game, and the issue is a jump that can't be made due to distance.  Very odd, and it was the nail in the coffin for this one.Up until that point I almost had to stop playing it several times because the number one way the game lives up to it's name is by making you sea sick.  The camera follow is abysmal, whipping around randomly as you go in and out of water, up and down from ladder to platform, and even just trying to swim around under water.  The violent thrashing of the camera, and some times inability to look past a very confined point when you need to look around is just terrible.Had those two issues been addressed in the years since release, it would at least be an enjoyable play with some engaging visuals.  It has a good balance of strategic shooter and light puzzle solver familiar to other games of the genre.Past that however, you note a couple other problems.  For one, it's very short.  Given what I read from those who were able to play the whole game, the killer point I mentioned is quite near the end.  That means the total play time is 4 hours or less.  Also, while they clearly had a great back story to the game world, very little of it is shared in the game.  This leads you to feel lost while things are being talked about in a very matter of fact way.  While not entirely unusual in similar games, the fact that bad guys just appear out of nowhere with no reason (didn't come in by door, just popped up) is off putting.  It's also quite obvious the bad guys must have gills, because unlike you they can stay under water indefinitely.  There is also the matter of the water control powers.  Apparently you get those right at the end, so I never got to experience them, but saving something like that for the last 20 minutes of the game?  Odd choice in my opinion.  In the end, other than the sea sickness there really is never a sense of fear of the water, which makes one wonder if there was an element the developers just failed to convey given the implied back story.All told, if you take a sea sick pill and get the game on a super steam sale for $1, it will pass a couple hours, and how hard can you complain for $1?  Well, I guess about as hard as this review...

HYDROPHOBIA: PROPHECY3rd person action/survival-adventure gameRating 2/10Interesting premise with nice water effects let down by clunky gameplay, bland locations and terrible voice acting.It should be quite good, the idea of fighting terrorists who have hijacked a floating city whilst trying to overcome hull breaches and numerous fires. Sadly even though the water looks fantastic and creates a few genuine moments of panic as rooms fill with water the rest of the gameplay falls short.  The worst of these is the gun play. It's a real chore and it feels like you're fighting the controls more than the terrorists. Thankfully they aren't that often but they undermine the rest of the game. The voice acting and writing isn't much better, lifeless and wooden which doesn't help the repetitive and boring gameplay of collecting keys to open a series of identical doors.They have great water tech, they just don't have a great game to go with it.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
Hydrophobia is an unsatisfying but engagingly short tense experience throughout.In this, we follow a young woman on a dangerous quest to escape a hijacked ship which then leads to unpredictable and intriguing outcomes through the true conspiracy. Though the main villain's reasons could be politically challenged, it's however a rather terrifying and eyeopening perspective on the instinct humans have for survival and balancing economical causes. At times, the protagonist and additional characters are tolerable but unfortunately lack enough depth to be totally memorable.The toughest gripe about this video game is purely knowing and literally seeing the potential spread between the mess that's the length and shortcomings within the story. It's either presenting itself as a disjointed short cinematic film purposely filled with unanswered questions or what would become a bloated adventurous game had it been thoroughly developed with care. Various things were heavily underutilized to an extent and would've given it a broader identity had there been various adjustments. There's particular creative sequences that surprisingly twists expectations but are merged between some tedious ideas that could either downgrade the enjoyment or levitate the replay value.Although its promising material was abruptly underdeveloped, it's definitively a self-destructive antique that shouldn't be lost or forgotten within the abyss of video game history.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												I bought this game a long time ago when I saw it on sale for next-to-nothing.  I was really shocked at the quality in this super-budget title!In the game you play a female protagonist in her linear adventure in a floating city. She is led through the bowels of the city's utility systems by a male co-worker who speaks in her earpiece.  He is watching most everything you do via the many security cameras in the city.  The exchanges are quite humorous now and then (and one time VERY humorous!).  The city is under attack from a villianess-of-the-week and her many rent-a-thugs.The game has controls similar to the Tomb Raider reboot although not quite as polished.  It also has Batman Arkham Assylum Detective vision for solving some simple puzzles.  The game also throws in some Half-Life 2 styled electricity and water puzzles.The thing that impressed me the most in this game are the water physics.  If the developer is reading this, my hat is off to you my friend.  The water physics are -=AMAZING=-!  The best I have seen in ANY videogame!Gun combat is not great but passable.  Fortunately this little missy is very tough and can take quite a few hits.  Combat in flooded rooms adds a new dimension as enemies are difficult to see on the other side of the water's surface.  I was frequently diving and surfacing to keep up with the enemies as they appeared above and below the water-line.I have not finished the game but I believe I am very close.  It is a short game, maybe 8 hours.  I read in the forums the final boss fight is a pain.PROS:+ -=Excellent=- value for your money.+ Novel gunplay situations in flooded areas.+ Varied gameplay from platforming to combat to environmental puzzles.+ THE FREAKING WATER PHYSICS!  Holy crap it is amazing!!+ Occasionally amusing banter between the main characters+ Documents and objects to collect along the way if you are into that.+ Graphics are quite good for a budget title.CONS:- Platforming is a little rough around the edges.  Character animations are a little stiff at times.- Environments can get a little samey as you make your way through the maintinence chambers under the city (where most of the game takes place).- While the main character looks nice, some of the other character models do not look so good.- Some of the environmental (Half Life 2 style) puzzles will test your patience.  These just aren't as fun as they were in the mid-2000's.The game is not perfect, but the value you get for the price is outstanding.  It would be worth a go at twice the asking price.  If you enjoyed the Tomb Raider reboot, this game is a no-brainer!

												Do you want to be an all-powerful water mage fighting a one woman war on eco-terrorists? Then this game may just be for you.I started playing this game with low hopes but was surprised at times and disappointed at others. There were of course a few fun things and a couple of moments that stood out above the rest as memorable. At the begining I really enjoyed myself yet it was mostly downhill from there. The water mechanics and powers later on were awesome to play with. But for the most part this game was meh.The combat is bland and forgetful, the weapons for the most part were serviceable and the supernatural abilities, although fun to use, only come into play towards the very end of the game. Also the plot, from what little there was, appeared rushed and had a very weak payoff. I wouldn’t recommend this game at full price, but at the low low sale price of 47 pence or 60 cents then there are worse things you can buy.Have fun. ^_^

content:
Posted: April 29, 2013
												Hydrophobia is ultimate a tech demo for the realistic water system with particle physics, fluid dynamics (or simulation thereof), and beautiful graphics. You play "Kate", a system engineer on the Queen of the World, a floating arcology (giant floating city) that was being attacked by nihilistic terrorists who want to unleash a nanobot plague and kill all the humans so the planet can start anew. As Kate, you survive, hack your way through the ship surviving various challenges such as fire,electricity, and water. Kate's spelunking, cliff-climbing experience comes in handy as she climbs, jumps and swims through various levels while combating these terrorists who wants to annihilate mankind. The game gets extremely buggy near the end, with disappearing objects and disappearing bosses. It is short (I finished in merely a few hours, and I'm a slow player) and it is an experience, albeit, probably not one that needs to be repeated.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												"Hydrophobia" is a action - adventure indie game by a developer called "Dark Energy Digital" and published by "Microsoft Studios". It uses the "Hydro engine" for some excellent dynamic water effects   In the story mode you play as a female protagonist "Kate willson". The opening cut scene indicates that she has a bad experince with the water, but the mejority of the gameplay is set only in the water and charecter doesn't seem to have any problem with that. Besides this narrative - gameplay disconnection the setting is quite intresting. You will also get water manipulating powers, but pretty late in the game. there is a main antagonist mila who leads a group of solders called "Malthusians". Let's not spoil the story over here for those who haven't played the game yet.   As in the case of gameplay, it's a generic 3rd person cover based shooter with some boring platforming and puzzle solving. It's mediocre at the best, but the game really shines in graphics department. It maynot be a lookup now, but for a 2011 indie game it's really well designed. As told before it has some best quality looking water effects. Hydro engineis capable of dynamic water flowing, which means the water in the game will act like real water and will consume empty spaces. Don't expect any crysis level detail or rendering, but the environments are quite nicely done. as far as the voice and music is concerned it is sitly above average.since it's a indie game, can't complain much abot that.   he game's narration leaves more question than it answers, and it is really a short game. " 4 hours ", that's all you need to complete the game. The additional challenge mode is fun for first 2-3 times only. so if the game is on sale it's a definate buy, but for the full price just ignore it. I am supporting the game only because i want to see a prequel or a sequel fleshing out the idea's of the original game. For me this setting has a lot of potential and it pains me that it is getting wasted like this. Since the developer closing doors in 2011, my will be a wish only. i hope it won't be the case

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												Primary conclusion: Best bought for game research/curiosity and little else. It's only an average third-person shooter, with an unfortunately short-lived exploration of a unique mechanic (water manipulation, towards the end of the game). Sell a few Steam cards, nab it during a sale, jump in with low expectations and enjoy a few hours of fairly impressive water simulation whilst shooting suicidal baddies (no really, that's their whole gig, convincing people to kill themselves, you'll see it all throughout the game, not advised if suicidal).The good attempts:Dynamic environmental element. Remember the old firefighting games? Replace fire with water then briefly give you control over it, that's Hydrophobia.Charming dialogue. While it doesn't do it very well, at least it tried something a little more lighthearted and fun compared to some other games.Emphasis on environmental awareness. Not in the save the world propaganda, but in keeping an eye out for electrical wires and the standard explosive tanks sitting about. It was nice that these options were available and encouraged through the unusual point system.Scan/MAVI view. This was a neat little trick to hide stuff in the environment without it being terribly obvious, and could have been used better, but where it was used, it was alright. With a longer game and better level design, it might have been better.The bad attempts: Voice acting. This wasn't the worst, but it was absolutely along mediocre lines. The main character, who with more development might have proved interesting, was especially average. Her partner in crime, Scoot, was somewhat better, but not by much.Platforming. This is probably the most offensively poor part of the game, I think. When it works properly, it's passable, but when it fails due to needing to be very precise, it's just frustrating. Fortunately there were only maybe three spots that made this especially noticeable in the game, but that's three too many, in my book.Game length. I'm not sure how this game's development went, if it was extended over and over to get the water simulation down or what, but the end result was much too short and the most unique gameplay element introduced way too late. Even trying to find everything in the game in a single pass (which to be fair I didn't manage), I beat it in about 4 hours. For $5 that's not too bad, and on sale for $.50 that's especially okay, but you probably won't find yourself replaying it.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
TL;DR:I believe this is a very solid game and absolutley think I got my moneys worth out of it.And I'd really like to see a sequel.Pros:So the water, it's effects and how movements are in it look and feel stunningly real!Runs really smooth even on my several year old laptop even though you have all theese water effects.Overall graphics are great.Sound and music is OK.Story is OK.Level Design is nice, even though pretty linear.Puzzles are OK, pretty straight forward and not hard thinkabouters.You can make choices (sometimes have to be quick about them) wheter to save someone or leave them to their fate.Really like the MAVI (Mobile Automated Visual Interface) and what you can do with it!You are like a smart commando triathlon acrobat; Climbing, swimming, balancing, rolling, swinging, jumping, shooting, hacking and everything else you're friggin' amazing at!Really awesome nanotech water ability!Cons:Controls are... OK, but they feel a little clunky.Animations sometimes (not at all always) felt a bit stiff, most apparent during cutscenes.Journal entries (who seems to be quite alot about what the protagonist feels and wants) and speech isn't always reflecting each other that well.Map in the MAVI was not that easy to follow (not that you had to look at it since there wasn't many places to go except forward).Sometimes while climbing, you get a fixed camera angle.You can't always look in the direction you want, seems like the water and other objects can block the camera so you can't look up for example (unless ou use the MAVI)).Sometimes the camera angle makes it so you can't see enemies while they can still shoot at you.If you stand to close to the edge of ventilation shafts, you will start to drift/float out of the vent shaft and fall down.So many collectibles it get's a bit tideous. Especially when some of them doesn't add anything ( IEY! I found a jar of pills that I can... uh, ok, just look at?).The choises you make doesn't seem to have any impact on the story... but it gives you a 'Medal' (yet another collectible)!Replay value; I'd say not that great unless you're an achievement junkie.Not to spoil it too much, but I found it a bit sad that I didn't get to play around with the water abilities more.Connclusion:First off I have to say that I was impressed with the water.How it moved and what you could do with it.Also I really liked the MAVI for some reason. It however was a tiny hard navigated/find the correct button for at first (my fault for not looking up the controls in the options menu) and the map in it wasn't maybe that easy to follow.But it was some fun elements used with it. Hacking security cameras, finding hidden messages etc.I would have wanted to have a longer campaign......and also I might have quite a list of cons...Still however;I believe this is a very solid game and absolutley think I got my moneys worth out of it.Maybe because I played on Hard without the permanent objective marker. Plus I also at first tried to run around everywhere getting all objects and documents so it might have taken me a little longer that some.And I'd really like to see a sequel.Maybe with a little more polish to some of the cons above and I'd probably say it would be worth quite a bit more that what they charge for this baby....but sadly seems like the studio has been shut down, but I still hope that someday this title will re-emerge to the surface for us all to enjoy.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												This game is often on sale for $0.99 or less, and at that price, I think it is definitely worth it. There are a lot of negative reviews for this game, and they aren't entirely wrong, but I don't think it's a terrible game. It has its ups and its downs and a full load of meh. So, let's break it down. Warning: Minor spoilers, but nothing that really gives away the story.Positives: - The water physics: they are definitely cool and a major positive. I wish more games would make such use of flowing water physics to affect the characters and environment. It is fun to use water flooding to disorient your enemies and sweep them off their feet, it's neat how the intensity, direction, and depth of the water flow affect your own movement and so on. In some cases, you can see flooded compartements behind glass barriers, and if you shoot out the glass, that water floods into an area to have several effects. Similarly, some destructable leaky bulkheads can be shot out for similar effects, in some areas even completely filling the corridors and compartments you are in, which can be a danger but finding an air-pocket is usually not too hard.- Use of the environment as weapons: not just the water, but leaky gas pipes, explosive panels and barrels, electrical panels and wires... all can be used strategically to trap and take out groups of bad guys.- The "Mavi" device: I found the way you can use it to scan and control somethings in the environment as well as see invisible messages and such pretty nifty. Not awesome, mind you, but cool enough.Negatives: - The voice acting: it's very weak, and I'll be surprised if you don't find the main character's voice to be whiny and annoying. - The keyboard and mouse controls: if you play this game, you'll definitely want to do it with a controller. Controlling with a keyboard and mouse is just really wonky. It's not perfect with a gamepad but it is much better and will save you a lot of frustration, especially later in the game when it comes to controlling water.- The final boss battle is pretty terrible and frustrating until you figure out what to do. It's darned near impossible with keyboard/mouse controls.The meh:- The story is really weak. It wanted to be something good, but the writers didn't pull it off well.- The gameplay in general. It's not terrible but it isn't very good either. It tries to combine a lot of things: cover-based shooting, tomb-raider style climbing and platforming, and a bit of "magic" in the form of a nanobot infection giving you the ability to somewhat control the water. But it doesn't do any of these these things particularly well. - The challenge room is pretty dull (unlocked upon completing the game), and the gameplay is not good enough to make it much fun. Only worth playing if you must go for 100% achievements. This game doesn't do a lot, so don't expect a lot. It wanted to be something amazing and utterly failed at that, but there is fun to be had.  I think you can easily get several hours of enjoyment out of it for $0.99 when it's on sale, but don't go in with high expectations and you won't find yourself being too disappointed. Again, playing it with a controller is pretty much a must.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												tl;dr: Play this for... awesome water effects, nice atmosphere and story, varied gameplayAccept... controls that are a little fiddly sometimes, especially during shootouts (gamepad)Be prepared... for the plot to rush to a sudden, pretty unsatisfiying ending from a certain point---First, look and physics of the water are simply incredible and contribute a lot to the nice atmosphere of the game. I was really impressed especially by the movement of the water and the fluent (haha...) way the character reacts to it. This game includes climbing passages (solid and fun), cover mechanic shootouts (a little fiddly sometimes), some riddles (rather easy, but some are original) and more... Overall game duration does not offer enough time to exploit the potential of all gameplay mechanics (e.g. different ammunition types are almost irrelevant)I play games like this primarily for the story, but attach a lot of value on gameplay and controls. Controls feel a little clumsy in certain situations, but are fine overall.The plot starts out and evolves nicely ... up to one point. Then all of a sudden the story kind of collapses and then rushes to a sudden end, leaving a lot unanswered. This felt really disappointing and left me very unsatisfied. However, remembering the early phases of the game I still recommend this game for its atmosphere, water effects and varied gameplay.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Hydrophobia: Prophecy is a 1 of a kind game thats for sure. Simply put it's a very short game that can be comfortably completed with in 2-5 hrs, so dont expect too much for your buck. Don't get me wrong with me saying that, I still found it fun to a degree with its water physic element.Is it worth $5, that would depend if your a full on game collector. Personally I would grab it on special.The game itself has a great concept and Idea, with a Sci-Fi feel and an Action RPG element to it and can leave an opening to a great series, mods, etc...The only way I can describe this game, it is like playing Tomb Raider 1-3 with the puzzle aspect to it, Metal Gear Solid 1 & 2 with the weapon changing also with a Mass Effect FOV movement feel.StoryWell the stoyline is very basic, your on a ship and a group of terrorist has taken over and killing innocents to claim a product that is made on the ship. They want to use it as a weapon and take over the world. You and a work collegue are working together as a team to stop them while the ship is sinking and hacking into computer systems, doors, etc.. just to try and stay 1 step ahead of the terrorist.LikesGame concept and has potential to expand.Didnt mind the movie scenes.Graphics was alright for its time.KB/M or Controller setup was ok and workable but could be better.DislikesFound the voice acting very bland and the constant whiney voice started to get annoying after a while.Very little dialog and variety.Too Short.Music found very boring and not thrilling. (Sounded like a B grade James Bond style movie playing in the background).Shooting in general the hit boxes are a hit and miss.Boss fight is a real disapointment with the hit boxes and movement of the barrels to strike.IssuesIMPORTANT: High end PC's be sure to have VSYNC turned on when playing this game otherwise you wont be able to jump and leap from place to place. The game does sit comfortably at 50-60 FPS depending on your system.Sound occasionaly cuts in and out.Personal Rating: 7/10

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												Hydrophobia is a puzzle/action/platformer akin to games like Tomb Raider, Prince of Persia, Legacy of Kain and countless other titles that we have probably played at one point or another. It's extremely atmospheric and it's got great visualizations (particularly the water effect- no kidding, right?) and sound. Here's the break down:THE GOOD: Stuff I liked.1. The WaterThe water is, as the name implies, the cornerstone of this game. It is the reason for the game's interesting atmosphere and environment based puzzles. The physics, graphics and visualizations (movement of waves, transition from surface to underwater, water on camera, etc) are superb. Best water effects I've seen in a game. Period.2. The Environment Interaction/ MovementI really enjoyed the layout of the levels and their design in general. There was a decent mix of swimming and climbing, giving each zone a level of depth that I don't often notice in other games (save for some of the ones I mentioned previously). Or maybe it's just because I was actually able to interact with it to such a high degree that made it interesting. This includes shooting out glass doors, blasting through bulkheads and raising the ambient water level. Very cool experience.3. NAVI MechanicI really enjoyed the NAVI mechanic. The protagonist comes equipped with a transparent PDA gadget that acts as your GUI in the game, keeping all your notes, grants access to your in game menus, highlights secret messages in the game and enables you to do all your non-combat trickery (hacking, opening doors, etc). 4. PRICE!!! $$$!!I think I bought the game on sale for $0.50? So in the end it was money well spent. ^_^The BAD: Stuff that was 'Meh.'1, Clunky MovementSo, while you can do all this neat stuff like roll, climb, swim and cling to cover... the controls felt somewhat unresponsive. Often I'd lose the ability to shoot around cover and have to back off and re-cling to get it working again. Likewise, occasionally the game would ignore a command to dive, roll, or jump. The fact that it occurred sporadically made it that much more of an aggravation when these missed commands would pop up... particularly in a heated, combat situation!2. *Occasional* Camera Angles from HellAgain, these didn't happen very often but when they did it was really difficult to get out of them. It most often happened while swimming and most usually in tight corridors. Of course, this is typically a problem of any game with a high degree of mobility in a given environment. 3. BacktrackingI don't mind a whole lot of backtracking personally. Given the NAVI's ability to help you perceive new things in the environment and the changing level of water, I'd rank this game about equal with such games as Legacy of Kain and Chrono Trigger. OF COURSE, there's backtracking... the designers want to show you how a place has changed. So I don't think it's a problem, but a lot of other reviews did. 4. 'Easy' Combat...?I played the game on Normal mode and died a total of 2 (maybe 3?) times while in combat. The badguy AI is fairly responsive in my opinion: when you don't shoot at it, they sneak closer to you. When you do, they scramble for cover. They try to flank you, etc, etc. They don't do any of this quickly, but they do it. They also deal enough damage that you can't go barreling in guns blazing very often either. But, if you're like me and you rock the sneaky/cautious/clever game style, you'll probably breeze through the game since there's ample opportunity for you to use environmental hazards to your advantage. This is NOT Call of Duty, Counterstrike, or anything resembling a "real" shooter. It just happens you can shoot things. 5. Voice ActingI've seen a lot of bad reviews because of voice acting... but honestly, I've heard a LOT worse (none come to mind this instant, but we've all heard worse). Plus, there's not a whole lot of it. I actually think the worst voice acting comes mainly from the protagonist (which is unfortunate) because I thought the acting of the antagonist and your plucky tech support ally were decent enough (if not reading from a very unimaginative script). THE UGLY: Stuff that's unforgivable (imho). In order,1. Repetitive game play and goals. The whole game is about finding keys to locked doors, almost without exception. This sucks. I'm just glad the environment was fun to navigate to make me forget that this was all I was doing. Blah. 2. Very few upgrades/collectables/etc. You pick up about 3 'new' abilities that you use sporadically throughout the game. There was also about 6 different types of ammo you could collect... but you really never needed it until the end of the game. This is one extremely crucial difference between this game and the likes Legacy of Kain and Prince of Persia (also games like Metroid, Castlevania and Megaman)… you never really feel like your power level advances.There is one HUGE exception to this complaint however, which brings me to...3. INCREDIBLY SHORT GAME!The final and coolest upgrade you get in the whole game is discovered and unlocked LITERALLY minutes before the game ends at the one and only boss fight. Not only is it a cruel move to throw a new game mechanic at you without giving you sufficient time to practice using it, but you also don’t get to enjoy it for more than a few minutes! Unforgivable! >_<Overall, if you can snag this game for less than the price of a bottle soda at the gas station AND have a few hours to kill, you may as well pry what fleeting joy you can from it’s very beautiful, if somewhat flawed and arthritic fingers.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												This game looks promising, and could have potential, but ends up wasting what it has with clunky controls and with just how short the game is.First off, the good points. The graphics are very good, especially the water and the way it flows between rooms. The near-future sci-fi setting is above-average and shows quite a bit of promise.Unfortunately, the bad points significantly outweight the good for this game. The controls need quite a bit of work. For simply walking around they're fine, but the jumping controls are extremely spotty. I died far too many times because the character wouldn't jump or would jump the wrong direction. Also, the cover system doesn't work consistenly (won't always go into cover when you need it, randomly can't shoot around corners, sometimes randomly jumps out of cover) which makes some of the firefights later in the game quite frustrating.The sci-fi setting, as interesting as it is, is woefully underutilized. The game supposedly takes place on a floating city, but you never actually see it (the quick glimpse out the window at the beginning notwithstanding). For all I know this could be in a secret underwater base or in tunnels deep below a conventional city.The water powers are a cool concept, but the clunky controls combined with the fact that you don't actually get them until almost the end of the game and that there is only really one power was a big letdown since it was one of the selling points of the game for me.Finally, the biggest weakness of this game is just how short it is. I blew through it in 4 hours without a walkthrough and with dying a significant number of times due to the controls. There is no closure on the story (unless it's in a hidden video after the credits). Sure, you stop the bad guys, but what happens to the city?I feel like the concepts behind this game are solid, the setting and the basic gameplay ideas are spot on, but the poor execution and lack of content really hurts this game.Unfortunately this game is from 2011 and it's been a long time since the last update so I'm not confident that there will be any further improvements. Not recommended.
